conclusion: Shadows form due to the blocking of light by an opaque object. The shape and size of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object and the surface where the shadow falls.

When the light source moves backwards, it means the light is coming from a farther distance. This affects the angle at which the light strikes the objects and the surface, thus altering the size and shape of the shadows.
The scene shows four objects above slabs: a red box, a birdcage, a black lampshade-like object, and an ornate cross-like object.
The objects cast shadows labeled A, B, C, and D on the ground.

premise: When the light source moves backwards, the angle at which the light strikes the objects becomes steeper.
conclusion: The shadows will generally become smaller because the light has less depth to spread across the surface.

premise: Shadow A is formed by the red box. When the light source moves backwards, the angle at which the light strikes the box becomes steeper.
Shadow B is cast by the black object within the birdcage. When the light source moves backwards, the angle at which the light strikes the object becomes steeper.
Shadow C is cast by the black lampshade-like object. When the light source moves backwards, the angle at which the light strikes the object becomes steeper.
Shadow D is cast by the ornate cross-like object. When the light source moves backwards, the angle at which the light strikes the object becomes steeper.

When the light source moves backwards, the shadows move forward under the objects and become shorter and smaller due to the increased angle between the light illuminating the object and the horizontal direction.
conclusion: A, B, C, and D move forward under the objects and become shorter and smaller.
